Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Nano-Building Block Toolboxes for Programmable Self-Assembly of Nanostructures with Arbitary Shapes and Functions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for research enabling the development of practical, controllable, and repeatable methods for both modeling and implementing self-assembled nanostructures, and to couple structure to the function of the nanoassembly. The first goal is to develop a nano-building block toolbox termed 'Nano-Toolbox' for the programmable self-assembly of nanostructures with arbitrary shapes and arbitrary functions. This is to be accomplished using an aqueous-phase ligand replacement technique to control the number, placement, and orientation of the DNA, which does the assembly, on various nanoparticles. The second goal is to develop practical methods to design assemblies using the building blocks, and to incorporate functional response into the design process. Third, to demonstrate the controllability and scalability of our approach, the resulting Nano-Toolbox will be used to construct multimodal and multifunctional 3D hybrid nanocomposites in different sizes and shapes with enhanced optical response over several wavelength bands, allowing us to acquire more comprehensive, accurate and reliable information using multiple imaging and therapeutic modalities.

This research has the potential to translate a nanoscale design for a structure into observable, macroscopic functions and material properties. Thus, the research advances nanotechnology closer to the goal of bottom-up manufacture of programmable materials and devices with new, enhanced properties and functionality. In addition, it provides the capability for functional, reliable, and scalable techniques for manufacturing more complicated and controlled multifunctional nanostructures that incorporate diverse nanocomponents for specific applications. If successful, the results of this research have the potential to provide standardized design and laboratory procedures for 'second-generation' multifunctional architectures at all scales and in all three dimensions. Thus, this research has high potential to transform many fields of research, including biology, chemistry, physics, medicine, and materials science and engineering. For example, nanostructures with better plasmonic response and multimodal characteristics might impact sensing applications in biology and medicine, therapeutics, and photovoltaic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering multiple molecular/nanoscale particles into structures with "customized" sizes and shapes has the potential to transform many fields of science and engineering, ranging from optoelectronics and nanophotonics to molecular/nano sensing and nanomedicine. DNA-guided self-assembly has the promise to program matter at a molecular scale for new material properties. Nevertheless, the design of the structures producing these new properties is difficult, and experimental progress is based upon trial and error. Also, accurate, scalable, and high-rate modular assembly of heterogeneous nanocomponents into multifunctional nanoarchitectures still remains a challenge. This project is dedicated to the development of effective and efficient routes to programmable integration of multifunctional hierarchical nanocomposites with controls over size, shape, and composition, coupling structure to the function of the nanoassembly. The centerpieces of our technical approach include:

  • A fabrication technology of nanoparticle building blocks (nBLOCKs), namely nanotoolbox technology, with DNA at defined locations, in defined 3D orientations, and with true anisotropy by attaching distinct DNA sequences at different locations on a particle,
  • Practical models for design of nBLOCKs and their assembly to aid in the experiments to assemble nanostructures with controls over their geometric configurations, and
  • Demonstration of the capability of our nanotoolbox technology for modular self-assembly of nanoparticles at all scales and in all dimensions.

The following summarize the key outcomes of this project:

  • Revision and optimization of our anisotropic monofunctionalization technology [1,2] that enables controls over the number, placement, and orientation of bio-functional ligands, particularly DNA, on various nanoparticles to increase the purity and yield as well as the functionality during their assembly,
  • Design and modeling of a new strategy to develop a simpler and more efficient method for modular self-assembly of nanoparticle structures at all scales by incorporating stereospecific helical twisting of DNA interactions into nBLOCK design, and
  • Validation of the new strategy through proof-of-concept experiments, demonstrating that nBLOCKs could build nanoparticle structures with defined shapes and sizes in all dimensions.

The validations of the nBLOCK capability and our new strategy for modular self-assembly of nanoparticles grants further investigations to fully realize its potential to produce nanoparticle composite structures with the properties desired in programmable matter, i.e., arbitrary, anisotropic shapes of structures with specific, desired functions, and precision difficult to achieve with existing methods. Detailed reaction optimizations and the generalizations to various nanoparticles should be further investigated. However, the key outcomes in the project demonstrate the potential of our protocols and strategies developed in this project, enabling the realization of programmable assemblies of nanostructures not only with complicated shapes, but also with the ability to tune their functions. This should drive innovations in hybrid fused technologies for many applications, including electronic devices, photonic circuits and medical theranostics.

[2] Kim, J.-W., Kim, J.-H. & Deaton, R. DNA-linked nanoparticle building blocks for programmable matter. Angewandte Chemie International Edition 50, 9185-9190 (2011).
